org.joml

Class MatrixStack

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.joml.MatrixStack
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class MatrixStack
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Resembles the matrix stack known from legacy OpenGL.

    The operation names and semantics resemble those of the legacy OpenGL matrix stack.

    As with the OpenGL version there is no way to get a hold of any matrix instance within the stack. You can only load the current matrix into a user-supplied Matrix4f instance.

    Author:
    Kai Burjack
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • MatrixStack

        public MatrixStack(int stackSize)
        Create a new MatrixStack of the given size.

        Initially the stack pointer is at zero and the current matrix is set to identity.

        Parameters:
        stackSize - the size of the stack. This must be at least 1

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public MatrixStack clear()
        Dispose of all but the first matrix in this stack and set the stack counter to zero.

        The first matrix will also be set to identity.

        Returns:
        this

        public MatrixStack loadMatrix(Matrix4f mat)
        Load the given Matrix4f into the current matrix of the stack.
        Parameters:
        mat - the matrix which is stored in the current stack matrix
        Returns:
        this

        Load the values of a column-major matrix from the given FloatBuffer into the current matrix of the stack.
        Parameters:

        Returns:

        Parameters:

        offset - the offset into the array

        public MatrixStack pushMatrix()
        Increment the stack pointer by one and set the values of the new current matrix to the one directly below it.
        Returns:

      • popMatrix

        public MatrixStack popMatrix()
        Decrement the stack pointer by one.

        This will effectively dispose of the current matrix.

        Returns:
        this

      • get

        public Matrix4f get(Matrix4f dest)
        Store the current matrix of the stack into the supplied dest matrix.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        dest

      • get

        public MatrixStack get(FloatBuffer dest)
        Store the current matrix into the supplied FloatBuffer at the current buffer position.

        This method will not increment the position of the given FloatBuffer.

        If you want to specify the offset into the FloatBuffer at which the matrix is stored, you can use get(int, FloatBuffer), taking the absolute position as parameter.

        Parameters:
        dest - the destination FloatBuffer into which to store the column-major values of the current stack matrix
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        get(int, FloatBuffer), Matrix4f.get(int, FloatBuffer)

      • get

        public MatrixStack get(int index,
                       FloatBuffer dest)
        Store the current matrix into the supplied FloatBuffer starting at the specified absolute buffer position/index.

        This method will not increment the position of the given FloatBuffer.

        If you want to store the matrix at the current buffer's position, you can use get(FloatBuffer) instead.

        Parameters:
        index - the absolute position into the FloatBuffer
        dest - will receive the values of this matrix in column-major order
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        get(FloatBuffer), Matrix4f.get(FloatBuffer)

      • get

        public float[] get(float[] dest,
                   int offset)
        Store the column-major values of the current matrix of the stack into the supplied float array at the given offset.
        Parameters:
        dest - the destination float array into which to store the column-major values of the current stack matrix
        offset - the array offset
        Returns:
        dest

      • getDirect

        public Matrix4f getDirect()
        Get a reference to the current matrix of the stack directly without copying its values to a user-supplied matrix like in get(Matrix4f).

        Note that any changes made to this matrix will also change the current stack matrix!

        Returns:
        the current stack matrix

      • translate

        public MatrixStack translate(float x,
                             float y,
                             float z)
        Apply a translation to the current matrix by translating by the given number of units in x, y and z.

        If C is the current matrix and T the translation matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * T. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * T * v, the translation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        x - the offset in x
        y - the offset in y
        z - the offset in z
        Returns:
        this

      • translate

        public MatrixStack translate(Vector3f xyz)
        Apply a translation to the current matrix by translating by the number of units in the given Vector3f.

        If C is the current matrix and T the translation matrix, then the new matrix will be C * T. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * T * v, the translation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        xyz - contains the number of units to translate by
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        translate(float, float, float)

      • scale

        public MatrixStack scale(float x,
                         float y,
                         float z)
        Apply scaling to the current matrix by scaling by the given x, y and z factors.

        If C is the current matrix and S the scaling matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * S. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * S * v, the scaling will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        x - the factor of the x component
        y - the factor of the y component
        z - the factor of the z component
        Returns:
        this

        public MatrixStack scale(Vector3f xyz)

        If C is the current matrix and S the scaling matrix, then the new matrix will be C * S. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * S * v, the scaling will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        xyz - contains the factors to scale by
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        scale(float, float, float)

      • scale

        public MatrixStack scale(float xyz)
        Apply scaling to the current matrix by uniformly scaling all unit axes by the given xyz factor.

        If C is the current matrix and S the scaling matrix, then the new matrix will be C * S. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * S * v, the scaling will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        xyz - the factor for all components
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        scale(float, float, float)

      • rotate

        public MatrixStack rotate(float ang,
                          float x,
                          float y,
                          float z)
        Apply rotation to the current matrix by rotating the given amount of degrees about the given axis specified as x, y and z component.

        If C is the current matrix and R the rotation matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the rotation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        ang - the angle is in degrees
        x - the x component of the axis
        y - the y component of the axis
        z - the z component of the axis
        Returns:
        this

        If C is the current matrix and R the rotation matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the rotation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        ang - the angle in degrees
        axis - the axis to rotate about
        Returns:

        Apply a rotation transformation, rotating about the given AxisAngle4f, to the current matrix.

        If C is the current matrix and R the rotation matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the rotation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        angleAxis - the AxisAngle4f (needs to be normalized)
        Returns:
        this

      • loadIdentity

        public MatrixStack loadIdentity()
        Set the current matrix to identity.
        Returns:
        this

      • multMatrix

        public MatrixStack multMatrix(Matrix4f mat)
        Post-multiply the given matrix mat against the current matrix.

        If C is the current matrix and M the supplied matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * M. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * M * v, the supplied matrix mat will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        mat - the matrix to multiply this matrix with
        Returns:
        this

      • lookAt

        public MatrixStack lookAt(Vector3f position,
                          Vector3f centre,
                          Vector3f up)
        Apply a "lookat" transformation to the current matrix for a right-handed coordinate system, that aligns -z with center - eye.

        If C is the current matrix and L the lookat matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * L. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * L * v, the lookat transformation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        position - the position of the camera
        centre - the point in space to look at
        up - the direction of 'up'. In most cases it is (x=0, y=1, z=0)
        Returns:
        this

      • lookAt

        public MatrixStack lookAt(float eyeX,
                          float eyeY,
                          float eyeZ,
                          float centerX,
                          float centerY,
                          float centerZ,
                          float upX,
                          float upY,
                          float upZ)
        Apply a "lookat" transformation to the current matrix for a right-handed coordinate system, that aligns -z with center - eye.

        If C is the current matrix and L the lookat matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * L. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * L * v, the lookat transformation will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        eyeX - the x-coordinate of the eye/camera location
        eyeY - the y-coordinate of the eye/camera location
        eyeZ - the z-coordinate of the eye/camera location
        centerX - the x-coordinate of the point to look at
        centerY - the y-coordinate of the point to look at
        centerZ - the z-coordinate of the point to look at
        upX - the x-coordinate of the up vector
        upY - the y-coordinate of the up vector
        upZ - the z-coordinate of the up vector
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector3f, Vector3f, Vector3f)

      • lookAlong

        public MatrixStack lookAlong(float dirX,
                             float dirY,
                             float dirZ,
                             float upX,
                             float upY,
                             float upZ)
        Apply a rotation transformation to the current matrix to make -z point along dir.

        If C is the current matrix and L the lookalong matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * L. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * L * v, the lookalong transformation will be applied first!

        This is equivalent to calling lookAt with eye = (0, 0, 0) and center = dir.

        Parameters:
        dirX - the x-coordinate of the direction to look along
        dirY - the y-coordinate of the direction to look along
        dirZ - the z-coordinate of the direction to look along
        upX - the x-coordinate of the up vector
        upY - the y-coordinate of the up vector
        upZ - the z-coordinate of the up vector
        Returns:
        this

      • lookAlong

        public MatrixStack lookAlong(Vector3f dir,
                             Vector3f up)
        Apply a rotation transformation to the current matrix to make -z point along dir.

        If C is the current matrix and L the lookalong matrix, then the new current matrix will be C * L. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * L * v, the lookalong transformation will be applied first!

        This is equivalent to calling lookAt with eye = (0, 0, 0) and center = dir.

        Parameters:
        dir - the direction in space to look along
        up - the direction of 'up'
        Returns:
        this

      • perspective

        public MatrixStack perspective(float fovy,
                               float aspect,
                               float zNear,
                               float zFar)
        Apply a symmetric perspective projection frustum transformation to the current matrix.

        If C is the current matrix and P the perspective projection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * P. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * P * v, the perspective projection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        fovy - the vertical field of view in degrees
        aspect - the aspect ratio (i.e. width / height)
        zNear - near clipping plane distance
        zFar - far clipping plane distance
        Returns:
        this

      • ortho

        public MatrixStack ortho(float left,
                         float right,
                         float bottom,
                         float top,
                         float zNear,
                         float zFar)
        Apply an orthographic projection transformation to the current matrix.

        If C is the current matrix and O the orthographic projection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * O. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * O * v, the orthographic projection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        left - the distance from the center to the left frustum edge
        right - the distance from the center to the right frustum edge
        bottom - the distance from the center to the bottom frustum edge
        top - the distance from the center to the top frustum edge
        zNear - near clipping plane distance
        zFar - far clipping plane distance
        Returns:
        this

      • frustum

        public MatrixStack frustum(float left,
                           float right,
                           float bottom,
                           float top,
                           float zNear,
                           float zFar)
        Apply an arbitrary perspective projection frustum transformation to the current matrix.

        If C is the current matrix and F the frustum projection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * F. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * F * v, the frustum projection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        left - the distance along the x-axis to the left frustum edge
        right - the distance along the x-axis to the right frustum edge
        bottom - the distance along the y-axis to the bottom frustum edge
        top - the distance along the y-axis to the top frustum edge
        zNear - the distance along the z-axis to the near clipping plane
        zFar - the distance along the z-axis to the far clipping plane
        Returns:
        this

      • reflect

        public MatrixStack reflect(float nx,
                           float ny,
                           float nz,
                           float px,
                           float py,
                           float pz)
        Apply a mirror/reflection transformation to the current matrix that reflects about the given plane specified via the plane normal and a point on the plane.

        If C is the current matrix and R the reflection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the reflection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        nx - the x-coordinate of the plane normal
        ny - the y-coordinate of the plane normal
        nz - the z-coordinate of the plane normal
        px - the x-coordinate of a point on the plane
        py - the y-coordinate of a point on the plane
        pz - the z-coordinate of a point on the plane
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        Matrix4f.reflect(float, float, float, float, float, float)

      • reflect

        public MatrixStack reflect(Vector3f normal,
                           Vector3f point)
        Apply a mirror/reflection transformation to the current matrix that reflects about the given plane specified via the plane normal and a point on the plane.

        If C is the current matrix and R the reflection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the reflection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        normal - the plane normal
        point - a point on the plane
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        Matrix4f.reflect(Vector3f, Vector3f)

      • reflect

        public MatrixStack reflect(Quaternionf orientation,
                           Vector3f point)
        Apply a mirror/reflection transformation to the current matrix that reflects about a plane specified via the plane orientation and a point on the plane.

        This method can be used to build a reflection transformation based on the orientation of a mirror object in the scene. It is assumed that the default mirror plane's normal is (0, 0, 1). So, if the given Quaternionf is the identity (does not apply any additional rotation), the reflection plane will be z=0, offset by the given point.

        If C is the current matrix and R the reflection matrix, then the new matrix will be C * R. So when transforming a vector v with the new matrix by using C * R * v, the reflection will be applied first!

        Parameters:
        orientation - the plane orientation
        point - a point on the plane
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        Matrix4f.reflect(Quaternionf, Vector3f)
